text.p: Aerolineas Argentinas SA (ARSA) made a net profit of $3.6 million in the first seven months of this year, its first since privatisation, Iberia said on Friday.
Its passenger load factor was 64 percent in the period, said a spokesman for the Spanish flag carrier. Iberia still manages Aerolineas although it has sold all but 10 percent of its shareholding.

Aerolineas has gone through a major shake-up in the last few years. Chairman Manuel Moran, appointed by Iberia's parent company nearly three years ago, has cut the workforce to 4,700 from 7,000 and restructured the route network.
European flight sales rose 22 percent in the January to end July period compared with four percent on routes to the United States and 11 percent on internal routes, Iberia said.
Aerolineas's debt to Iberia is being cancelled as part of the sale of most of the Spanish carrier's stake to a holding company formed by Bankers Trust, Merrill Lynch and Iberia's parent Teneo.
This puts Aerolineas in a position to consider renewing the older aircraft in its fleet -- most of the seven Boeing 727s -- with similar sized planes.
